intro: Ferulago orphanidis, commonly known as the Cyprus bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the island of Cyprus. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its delicate, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky and limestone soils, thriving in the arid and semi-arid climates of its native habitat. Its leaves are finely divided and aromatic, while its flowers range in color from white to pale blue. Ferulago orphanidis is a rare and endemic species, making it a significant part of Cyprus's botanical heritage.
